column1: Other
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have chrrosis of the liver from fatty liver disease. Found out a few yrs ago after so much testing for fatigue. My gallbladder does not work at all but Dr's dont want to remove it for fear of bleeding out and making my condition worse. I just started this medication a few months ago and have found it a little hard to take 3 times a day but find that at least once a day has kept me out of the hospital for the last 3 months-was going about every 2 months for an average 6 days. So, Im not going to complain about it at all. It must be working somehow.

column1: Other
column2: dannyrgeorge, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been diagnosed with Non Alcoholic Fatty Liver disease. I had been advised of this condition years ago but all the doctors I ever saw never gave it much thought. I have high blood lipids and high triglycerides. I am not significantly overweight and do not drink nor smoke. I have for years expierienced abdominal pain episodes which doctors from some of the leading teaching institutions have not been able to diagnose correctly. I have had this condition for neary 15 years. The pain at times is unbearible, pain meds give some relief. Doctors at the Mayo Clinic in AZ believe my condition is due to the fatty liver. The liver itself has no nerves in it but the sac surrounding the liver is extremely sensitive and when inflammed can cause radiating abdominal pain and into the back. I have been on crestor and tricor for some time and now I am on the Urosodiol 1x3 300mg. I also was told to take Vitamin E daily with the Urosodiol. I am now starting to adjust to this med, side effects I have are slight headache,fatigue, sweating and metalic taste with drop in appetite.

column1: Inflammation with Fibrous Tissue Formation of Bile Ducts
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I actually have primary sclerosing cholangitis (as well as autoimmune hepatitis), but that's not an option.  I'll just say that I tolerate the drug well, and that it has helped keep my liver functions down.  It is a bit of a pain to take six pills a day, but I'm on other things, too, so that's not a huge deal.

column1: Gallstones
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have to take 4 pills every day, 2 pills 2 times a day.  It makes things very inconvenient, but it has prevented me from having surgery so far.  I was placed on blood thinners at the same time, so there are no major reactions with that as far as I know. Sometimes my stools are too soft and it reacts that way when I eat fatty foods.  The drug is normally VERY expensive (about $300/month for my dose).  My experience has been okay overall.
